However it does point to dynamics within the region along with the oversupply of oil in the global economy could potentially derail completion of the JCPOA requirements for declaration of implementation day in the nuclear deal.  The deepening of the sectarian divide among Sunnis and Shi'ites and its affect on proxy conflicts within the region could potentially affect the progress of implementation day requirements.   Iran has however indicated that does not intend to allow these factors to influence its ability to complete JCPOA requirements prior to the Februaryelection.  Reformists and conservatives in the Iranian theocratic political system have much to gain and provide considerable influence on the electoral outcomes.   Despite these concerns Iranian officials have indicated through its officials that (a) 'Atomic Energy Organization of Iran (AEOI) Spokesman Behrouz Kamalvandi stated on January 11 that he expects Iran to complete its initial commitments under the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) within seven days. Implementation Day, which initiates the removal of economic and financial sanctions against Iran, will occur when the International Atomic Energy Agency verifies that Iran has fulfilled its initial commitments; and (b) that ' An “informed source” told Fars News Agency that the core of the Arak heavy water reactor has been removed and filled with cement, thereby fulfilling one of Iran’s major commitments under the JCPOA. The move effectively prevents the Arak reactor from producing the plutonium levels required for a nuclear weapon."  Confirmation and verification of these developments by IAEA within the next two weeks or so increases the likelihood that Iran will complete its requirements prior to the 26 February 2016 election. January 12, 2016 | 16:09 GMT
An Iranian nuclear official denied that technicians dismantled the core of the country's heavy-water reactor and filled it with concrete, as was recently reported by Iran's Fars News Agency, AP reported Jan. 12. The official said Iran will instead sign a deal with China to modify the Arak reactor. He also spoke of plans to sell heavy water produced by the reconfigured reactor to the United States through a third country. Redesigning the Arak reactor so that it cannot produce plutonium for nuclear weapons is a key piece of Iran's nuclear agreement with the West.

Predictions of an imminent end to sanctions were echoed by European Union foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini, who said Monday in Prague that the implementation day of the Iran agreement “could come rather soon.” Last week, Secretary of State John F. Kerry said it was just “days away.” ++++++

http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2016/01/01/461610337/as-iran-moves-swiftly-on-nuclear-deal-sanctions-could-go-soon "Iran must still disable its heavy-water reactor at Arak, though that shouldn't take more than a couple weeks once it begins, says Ali Vaez, who follows Iran for the International Crisis Group. . . .  The other big component everyone is watching is the removal of thousands of centrifuges, which are used to enrich uranium, and that seems to be speeding right along. One reason the centrifuges seem to be coming out faster than expected is that the Iranians were evidently not very cautious when it came to removing about 10,000 older, inactive centrifuges, known as IR-1s.  Fitzpatrick says Iran may have considered them all but unusable after sitting idle so long, so they just pulled them out relatively quickly. They have been taking more time with some of the other models, but Vaez says the remaining 1,000 active IR-1s should be removed by the end of next week. Some more advanced models must also be dealt with.
. . . 
"Iranian negotiators originally predicted that completing its nuclear commitments it would only take two to three weeks, which was never seen as realistic in the West. But now even Yukiya Amano, the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which has to verify all these steps, says an implementation day by the end of January can't be ruled out. Analyst Ali Vaez also thinks that's possible, while Mark Fitzpatrick thinks early February may be more likely.
. . . 
"Hardline pressure isn't likely to die down soon, because there are important parliamentary elections coming up in March, and conservatives do not want President Hassan Rouhani and Iranian moderates to benefit politically from the lifting of sanctions. "For the president and a faction of Iranian moderates and reformers who helped elect him in 2013, playing up implementation day and the economic benefits that will follow could provide an important political boost. "However, Vaez notes that it's already too late for those economic benefits to reach the Iranian street in a big way before voters head to the polls in March. "Meanwhile, there are fights brewing over potential new sanctions involving a missile program that Iran argues isn't part of the nuclear deal. U.S. conservatives will be watching for anything that looks like Iran isn't living up to its commitments under the nuclear agreement.
The president has a lot to gain from pushing the implementation process forward.

http://nationalinterest.org/feature/iran-nuclear-deals-next-test-getting-through-the-iaea-14483 Active participation in the GJOpen project has been an interesting experience in many respects. One of which is that I find myself just "not getting" concepts that other people find so easily grasped. The relation of the IAEA board vote on the PMD to the JCPOA is one such concept. I am just not getting this connection as easily as others seem to. Am I incorrect in thinking that the JCPOA is an independent agreement? The PMD report is a line-item in the JCPOA, something to be accomplished. Is there language somewhere that holds the outcome of the PMD report/vote as having determinative influence on the JCPOA? If not, why are people making such a big deal over it? I'm just not getting it. While I can't help but agree with Mr. Hibbs (the author of the above cited article) as to any of his recommendations that fall within the bounds of those "as is the case for any other state subject to [IAEA] safeguards," I must disagree as to any recommendation which suggests any action beyond this. One concept I think I do get, and in fact think I am fairly clear upon, is that of "good faith." To seek to use the IAEA PMD report/board vote as a mechanism to add new requirements to the JCPOA through the back door, so to speak, is not a good faith action. "Iran attaches huge importance to closing the books on the allegations in its drive to lift all punitive measures against it and wipe the slate clean over its nuclear program."
Why? It is not, to my understanding, relevant to the JCPOA. I just don't get it.

Iran has stopped dismantling centrifuges in at least one of the country's nuclear facilities. Alireza Zakani, the head of the Iranian parliament's nuclear deal commission, said the deactivation of the centrifuges had stopped at the Fordo underground facility because of the lawmakers' letter to President Hassan Rohani. The move comes a few days after a group of hard-line lawmakers called on Rohani to stop dismantling centrifuges, which they claimed was being done too rapidly and not according to directives from Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. The dismantling of the centrifuges is part of the landmark nuclear deal that Iran signed with six world powers in Vienna in July that curbs Iran's controversial nuclear program in exchange for relief from international economic sanctions.

http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Report-Media-misleading-by-reporting-that-Iran-implementing-nuclear-deal-431936 OK. In a note regarding the analyses by @cmeinel and @morrell, I looked into the Arak reactor ( https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/36149 ), and I came to the conclusion, upon scanning portions of the document, that redesign of the Arak reactor was not required to achieve Implementation. The above Jerusalem Post article implies that this is not the case; viz., that the "signing off" on the Arak redesign is indeed required. And, in addition, that one signature remains outstanding; although no indication is given as to who that would-be signatory is. Since this is a definite conflict, I went back and reviewed the Agreement as to Arak. The JP article is correct, and I missed this requirement. As I understand it now, an international partnership is to be formed that will "certify the final design." As to Implementation Day, Iran must "conclude an official document that would define the responsibilities" of those international partners in the process of certification of the final redesign. So it's not the redesign that is required, but a document defining responsibilities as to redesign certification. [I could, but will not, plead that my error arose from the fact that the Agreement contains a typographical error -- a reference to paragraph 3 when they meant 8. I simply missed it.] This is an example of what I meant when I said earlier that beyond the efforts of Iran, the goodwill of the IAEA and other parties will be critical as to Iran achieving Implementation. Who knows why the signatory has not yet signed the document, but without that signature, no Implementation Day. And, just for completeness, Iran is also required to "make available for export" their "excess" supply of heavy water. I was aware of this requirement previously, but neglected to report it since I felt it was rather trivial. But who knows, that IAEA heavy water export inspector might be a real stickler.

Iran's current political leadership (Rouhani et al) is eager for implementation to occur before the elections, because going to the polls after clearing the way to lift sanctions will be a vote-winner for them. Conversely, this may be precisely why Iran's conservatives and security-minded establishment may not want implementation to occur that early. The IAEA is due to issue its report on 15 December, while elections are to be held on 26 February, If these dates hold, there are just ten weeks for Iran to comply with all prior requirements. Rouhani says Iran needs only 6 to 8 weeks, whereas the US thinks it will take over 6 months. The time period seems short, despite Rouhani's stated optimism.  However, I think everyone in Iran, moderate or conservative, wants sanctions to be lifted and they will do everything they can to achieve implementation. There are reports that preparatory work has already begun, ahead of the IAEA report. The only hitch I can see is that the conservatives may deliberately drag things out beyond the elections to prevent Rouhani's group from winning more votes.
